that some things are better left alone.
"I'm sorry, Mom. I was just curious," Lily said.
"I know, Lily. Curiosity is good, but you have to be gentle and respectful with living things. They have feelings too," Mom said.
Lily nodded. She learned something new. She said sorry to the cat and gave it a treat. She decided to weigh only things that did not mind. She still liked to be curious, but she also liked to be kind.

Her mom opened the door and saw Lily on her bed. She showed her the book and asked her why she did that. Lily looked at the book and felt sorry. She said she was sorry. She said she wanted to read the book, but she did not like it.

The bee was angry. It stung Lily on her finger. Lily cried out loud. It hurt a lot. She ran to her mom. Her mom hugged her and put some ice on her finger. She told Lily not to kiss the bees. She said the bees did not like that.

Once upon a time, there was a happy cat named Tom. Tom loved to play with yarn. Every day, he would find a ball of yarn and roll it around the house.
One day, Tom's yarn got stuck under a big chair. Tom tried to get it out, but he couldn't. He started to frown because he was sad. He wanted to play with his yarn.

and said, "Thank you, Max!"
Max felt proud that he could help his friend. But when they went back to play with the red wagon, they saw that it was broken. Max was sad, but Lily said, "Don't worry, Max. I forgive you. We can fix the wagon together."
So Max and Lily worked together to fix the wagon. They had so much fun playing together that they became best friends forever. And they always remembered to forgive each other when something went wrong.

hot and the ground was cracked.
"We made it!" said the little girl, feeling tired but happy.
Just then, a curious grasshopper hopped out of the long grass. He asked the little girl, "Where are you going?"
The little girl was very excited to have made a new friend. She took his hand and said, "We're on an adventure! Let's march east together."
So the little girl and her new grasshopper friend set off across the dry and dusty field, marching east to search for new adventures. They were never seen again, but it's said they were very happy
